rawContent:
I follow @againstgrmrs  that really opened my eyes to not allowing the grooming nature of the trans movement. 
I do believe some people are trans, but not every gay or bi teenager has to identify as the opposite sex, like they are being lead to believe. 

My daughter is more of a girly girl. Since she was a toddler, wore anything pink or sparkly she could find. My house was a pink glitter bomb for 10 years 
That stopped when I was avoiding the gay/ trans subject entirely. 
So we had to accept the possibility that she may want to dress like a boy now. She went by a boy name and hid it from us for months. 
After she got her hair cut short, she started wearing make up and curling her hair again. 
I see these as signs of needing acceptance being being very confused. 
We had her start seeing a therapist about 8 months ago 
and the skipping meals and cutting has come along more so with removing her off her online community in the last year. 

I told her about a month ago I was sick and tired of this being pushed further, after asking if 2 “boys” could spend the night. And I wasn’t putting my morals aside anymore for this. Because I just don’t agree and it’s harmful strange behavior. It helped ease the situation a little bit 

It’s been a tough battle but she’s still talking with us and opening up about her thoughts. So I don’t feel in the dark about how she’s navigating.
